Automated Federated Learning in Mobile Edge Networks — Fast Adaptation and Convergence

Chaoqun You,  Kun Guo, 
Gang Feng,  Peng Yang, 
and Tony Q. S. Quek C. You and T. Quek are with the Singapore University of Design and Technology, 487372, Singapore (e-mail: chaoqun_you@sutd.edu.sg and tonyquek@sutd.edu.sg).K. Guo is with the East China Normal University, Shanghai 200241, P.R.China (e-mail:kguo@cee.ecnu.edu.cn).G. Feng is with University of Electronic Science and Technology of China, Chengdu 611731, P.R.China (e-mail:fenggang@uestc.edu.cn).P. Yang is with the Beihang University, Beijing 100088, P.R.China (e-mail:yangp09@buaa.edu.cn).
Abstract

Federated Learning (FL) can be used in mobile edge networks to train machine learning models in a distributed manner. Recently, FL has been interpreted within a Model-Agnostic Meta-Learning (MAML) framework, which brings FL significant advantages in fast adaptation and convergence over heterogeneous datasets. However, existing research simply combines MAML and FL without explicitly addressing how much benefit MAML brings to FL and how to maximize such benefit over mobile edge networks. In this paper, we quantify the benefit from two aspects: optimizing FL hyperparameters (i.e., sampled data size and the number of communication rounds) and resource allocation (i.e., transmit power) in mobile edge networks. Specifically, we formulate the MAML-based FL design as an overall learning time minimization problem, under the constraints of model accuracy and energy consumption. Facilitated by the convergence analysis of MAML-based FL, we decompose the formulated problem and then solve it using analytical solutions and the coordinate descent method. With the obtained FL hyperparameters and resource allocation, we design a MAML-based FL algorithm, called Automated Federated Learning (AutoFL), that is able to conduct fast adaptation and convergence. Extensive experimental results verify that AutoFL outperforms other benchmark algorithms regarding the learning time and convergence performance.

Index Terms:
Fast adaptation and convergence, federated learning, model-agnostic meta-learning, mobile edge networks

I Introduction

In recent years, modern mobile user equipments (UEs) such as smart phones and wearable devices have been equipped with advanced powerful sensing and computing capabilities [1]. This enables their access to a wealth of data that are suitable for learning models, which brings countless opportunities for meaningful applications such as Artificial Intelligence (AI) medical diagnosis [2] and air quality monitoring [3]. Traditionally, learning models requires data to be processed in a cloud data center [4]. However, due to the long distance between the devices where data is generated and the servers in data centers, cloud-based Machine Learning (ML) for mobile UEs may incur unacceptable latencies and communication overhead. Therefore, Mobile Edge Computing (MEC) [5, 6] has been proposed to facilitate the deployment of servers near the base station (BS) at mobile edge networks, so as to bring intelligence to network edge.

In mobile edge networks, for a traditional ML paradigm, it is inevitable to upload raw data from mobile UEs to a server which could be deployed near the BS for model learning. However, the unprecedented amount of data created by mobile UEs are private in nature, leading to the increasing concern of data security and user privacy. To address this issue, Federated Learning (FL) has been proposed [7] as a new ML paradigm. FL in mobile edge networks refers to training models across multiple distributed UEs without ever uploading their raw data to the server. In particular, UEs compute local updates to the current global model based on their own local data, which are then aggregated and fed-back by an edge server, so that all UEs have access to the same global model for their new local updates. Such a procedure is implemented in one communication round and is repeated until a certain model accuracy is reached.

Despite its promising benefits, FL also comes with new challenges in practice. Particularly, the datasets across UEs are heterogenous. Not only does the number of data samples generated by UEs vary, but these data samples are usually not independent and identically distributed (non-i.i.d). Learning from such heterogeneous data is not easy, as conventional FL algorithms usually develop a common model for all UEs [8–10] such that, the global model obtained by minimizing the average loss could perform arbitrarily poorly once applied to the local dataset of a specific UE. That is, the global model derived from conventional FL algorithms may conduct weak adaptations to local UEs. Such weak adaptations will further restrict the convergence rate of the FL algorithms.

Multiple techniques are emerging as promising solutions to the data heterogeneity problem, such like adding user context [8], transfer-learning [9], multi-task learning [10], and Model-Agnostic Meta-Learning (MAML) [11]. Of all these techniques, MAML is the only one that not only addresses the heterogenous data problem, but greatly speeds up the FL learning process as well. MAML is a well-known meta-learning [12] approach that learns from the past experience to adapt to new tasks much faster. Such adaptations make it possible for MAML to develop well-behaved user-specific models. More specifically, MAML aims to find a sensitive initial point that learned from the past experience to conduct fast adaptations requiring only a few data points on each UE. With the learned initial model, MAML dramatically speeds up the learning process by replacing hand-engineered algorithms with an automated, data-driven approach [13]. Fortunately, in both MAML and FL, existing algorithms use a variant of gradient descent method locally, and send an overall update to a coordinator to update the global model. This similarity makes it possible to interpret FL within a MAML framework  [14, 15, 16, 17]. Such a simple MAML-based FL is termed as Personalized Federated Learning (PFL), and the algorithm that realizes PFL is termed as Personalized FederatedAveraging (Per-FedAvg). However, Per-FedAvg is a pure ML algorithm, and how to apply it into practical mobile edge networks remains unclear. Recently several attempts have been made to study the implementation of Per-FedAvg in practice. [18] proposes a framework to execute Per-FedAvg for intelligent IoT applications without considering Per-FedAvg’s strength in saving learning time. [19], although aims to achieve fast learning for IoT applications at the edge, does not consider the resource allocation in a practical mobile edge network. Therefore, to what degree a MAML-based FL algorithm expedites FL in mobile edge networks and under what conditions such benefit could be achieved still remain to be unexplored areas.

In order to quantify the benefit MAML brings to FL in mobile edge networks, we consider two aspects to minimize the overall learning time: optimizing learning-related hyperparameters as well as resource allocation. On the one hand, the typical FL hyperparameters, including the sampled data sizes across UEs and the number of communication rounds, have significant impact on the overall learning time and thus, these hyperparameters need to be carefully specified. On the other hand, the resource allocation should be considered to account for UEs’ practical wireless communication environments and limited battery lifetimes. Particularly, due to the existence of random channel gain and noise over wireless channels, the transmit power allocation on an UE will decide whether the transmitted updates from the UE can be successfully decoded by the edge server. Restricted by the limited battery lifetime, it will also determine whether the remaining energy on that UE is sufficient to support its local training.

It is non-trivial to solve the formulated optimization problem considering above two quantitative dimensions, given that the relationship between the variables (i.e., the sampled data sizes across UEs, the number of communication rounds, and the transmit power on UEs) and the model accuracy ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon is implicit. Therefore, we start with the convergence analysis of the MAML-based FL algorithm, by which the three variables are bounded as functions of ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon. After that, the formulated optimization problem can be approximatively decoupled into three sub-problems, each of which accounts for one of the three variables. Specifically, solving the first sub-problem gives an insight to achieve the required number of communication round. As for the other two sub-problems, we use the coordinate descent method [20] to compute the sampled data size and the transmit power of all UEs iteratively. In other words, we first give an initial value of the transmit power of UEs, and use it to compute the sampled data sizes in the second sub-problem; then with the attained sampled data sizes, we compute the transmit power in the third sub-problem. This process repeats until a certain model accuracy is achieved.

The solution to the optimization problem guides us to the design of Automated Federated Learning (AutoFL). AutoFL uses the results derived from the optimization problem to design the learning process, thereby quantifying as well as maximizing the benefit MAML brings to FL over mobile edge networks. More specifically, in each round k𝑘k, the BS first sends the current model parameter wksubscript𝑤𝑘w_{k} to a random subset of UEs. According to the given model accuracy ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon, the sampled data sizes and the transmit power of the selected UEs are determined by our proposed solution. Each selected UE then trains its local model with the determined sampled data size and then transmits the local update to the edge server with the determined transmit power. The server receives local updates from the selected UEs and decides whether these updates can be successfully decoded. Those successfully decoded updates are then aggregated to update the global model as wk+1subscript𝑤𝑘1w_{k+1}. Such a communication round is executed repeatedly until the model accuracy ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon is achieved. In this way, AutoFL is able to inherit the advantages of MAML over mobile edge networks, thereby conducting model learning with fast adaptation and convergence.

To summarize, in this paper we make the following contributions:

  • •

    We provide a comprehensive problem formulation for the MAML-based FL design over mobile edge networks, which can account for the impact of FL hyperparameters and network parameters on the model accuracy and learning time at the same time. Specifically, we jointly optimize the UEs’ sampled data size and transmit power, as well as the number of communication rounds, to quantify and maximize the benefit MAML brings to FL, by which the overall learning time is minimized under the constraint of model accuracy ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon and energy consumption.

  • •

    We analyse the convergence of MAML-based FL algorithm as the first step to solve the formulated problem. The convergence analysis makes the relationships between optimization variables and the model accuracy explicit, especially characterizes the sampled data size, the transmit power, and the number of communication rounds as functions of model accuracy ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon.

  • •

    Applying the obtained results of convergence analysis, the formulated problem is decoupled into three sub-problems. By solving these sub-problems, the number of communication rounds can be characterized using a closed-form solution, while the sampled data sizes and the transmit power of all UEs in each round can be achieved using the coordinate descent method. With the optimized hyperparameters and resource allocation, we further propose AutoFL with fast adaptation and convergence.

  • •

    By conducting extensive experiments with MNIST and CIFAR-10 datasets, we demonstrate the effectiveness and advantages of AutoFL over Per-FedAvg and FedAvg, two baseline FL algorithms in terms of learning time, model accuracy and training loss.

The rest of this paper is organized as follows. We first give the system model and problem formulation in Section II. Then we give the convergence analysis to make the formulated problem tractable in Section III. We recast the optimization problem and then propose the solutions to guide the design of AutoFL in Section IV. Extensive experimental results are presented and discussed in Section V. Finally, we conclude this paper in Section VI.

II System Model and Problem Formulation

Consider a typical mobile edge network with a edge server co-deployed with a BS and n𝑛n UEs, and the UEs are indexed by 𝒰={1,…,n}𝒰1…𝑛\mathcal{U}=\{1,\dots,n\}, as illustrated in Fig. 1. In this section, we first explain why the FL problem can be interpreted within the MAML framework. Based on this framework, we introduce our system model and problem formulation.

II-A Interpreting FL within the MAML framework

In FL, we consider a set of n𝑛n UEs which are connected with the server via the BS, where each UE has access only to its local data [7]. For a sample data point {x,y}𝑥𝑦\{x,y\} with input x𝑥x, the goal of the server is to find the model parameter w𝑤w that characterizes the output y𝑦y with loss function f​(w):ℝm→ℝ:𝑓𝑤→superscriptℝ𝑚ℝf(w):\mathbb{R}^{m}\rightarrow\mathbb{R}, such that the value of f​(w)𝑓𝑤f(w) can be minimized. More specifically, if we define fi​(w):ℝm→ℝ:subscript𝑓𝑖𝑤→superscriptℝ𝑚ℝf_{i}(w):\mathbb{R}^{m}\rightarrow\mathbb{R} as the loss function of UE i𝑖i, the goal of the server is to solve

minw∈ℝm⁡f​(w):=1n​∑i=1nfi​(w).assignsubscript𝑤superscriptℝ𝑚𝑓𝑤1𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛subscript𝑓𝑖𝑤\min_{w\in\mathbb{R}^{m}}f(w):=\frac{1}{n}\sum_{i=1}^{n}f_{i}(w). (1)

In particular, for each UE i𝑖i, we have

fi​(w):=1Di​∑(x,y)∈𝒟ili​(w;x,y),assignsubscript𝑓𝑖𝑤1subscript𝐷𝑖subscript𝑥𝑦subscript𝒟𝑖subscript𝑙𝑖𝑤𝑥𝑦f_{i}(w):=\frac{1}{D_{i}}\sum_{(x,y)\in\mathcal{D}_{i}}l_{i}(w;x,y), (2)

where li​(w;x,y)subscript𝑙𝑖𝑤𝑥𝑦l_{i}(w;x,y) is the error between the true label y∈𝒴i𝑦subscript𝒴𝑖y\in\mathcal{Y}_{i} and the prediction of model w𝑤w using input x∈𝒳i𝑥subscript𝒳𝑖x\in\mathcal{X}_{i}. Each UE i𝑖i has a local dataset 𝒟i={x∈𝒳i,y∈𝒴i}subscript𝒟𝑖formulae-sequence𝑥subscript𝒳𝑖𝑦subscript𝒴𝑖\mathcal{D}_{i}=\{x\in\mathcal{X}_{i},y\in\mathcal{Y}_{i}\}, with Di=|𝒟i|subscript𝐷𝑖subscript𝒟𝑖D_{i}=|\mathcal{D}_{i}| data samples. Since the datasets captured by the UEs are naturally heterogenous, the probability distribution of 𝒟isubscript𝒟𝑖\mathcal{D}_{i} across UEs is not identical.

MAML, on the other hand, is one of the most attractive technique in meta-learning. MAML is proposed to learn an initial model that adapts quickly to a new task through one or more gradient steps with only a few data points from that new task. Each task can be regarded as an object with its own dataset to learn, just like an UE in FL. MAML allows us to replace hand-engineered algorithms with data-driven approaches to learn initial parameters automatically.

To show how to exploit the fundamental idea behind the MAML framework [11] to design an automated variant of FL algorithm, let us first briefly recap the MAML formulation. In MAML, if we regard the tasks as UEs and assume each UE takes the initial model and updates it using one step of gradient descent with respect to its own loss function111A more general case is to perform multiple steps of gradient descent. However, this would lead to expensive cost of computing multiple Hessians. Therefore, for simplicity, throughout the whole paper we consider only one single step of gradient descent., problem (1) then changes to

minw∈ℝm⁡F​(w):=1n​∑i=1nfi​(w−α​∇fi​(w)),assignsubscript𝑤superscriptℝ𝑚𝐹𝑤1𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛subscript𝑓𝑖𝑤𝛼∇subscript𝑓𝑖𝑤\min_{w\in\mathbb{R}^{m}}F(w):=\frac{1}{n}\sum_{i=1}^{n}f_{i}(w-\alpha\nabla f_{i}(w)), (3)

where α≥0𝛼0\alpha\geq 0 is the learning rate at a UE. For UE i𝑖i, its optimization objective Fi​(w)subscript𝐹𝑖𝑤F_{i}(w) can be expressed as

Fi​(w):=fi​(w−α​∇fi​(w)).assignsubscript𝐹𝑖𝑤subscript𝑓𝑖𝑤𝛼∇subscript𝑓𝑖𝑤F_{i}(w):=f_{i}(w-\alpha\nabla f_{i}(w)). (4)

Such a transformation from problem (1) to (3) implies that the FL problem can be interpreted within the MAML framework. The FL algorithm proposed to solve (3) is termed as Personalized Federated Averaging (Per-FedAvg) [21, 14]. Per-FedAvg is inspired by FedAvg, which is proposed in [7] as a classic and general FL algorithm to solve (1) in a distributed manner.

Per-FedAvg is summarized in Algorithm 1. In each round k𝑘k (k=1,…,K)𝑘1…𝐾(k=1,\dots,K), the central BS randomly picks a set of UEs 𝒜ksubscript𝒜𝑘\mathcal{A}_{k} and then sends them the current model parameter wksubscript𝑤𝑘w_{k}. Each UE first adapts the global model wksubscript𝑤𝑘w_{k} to its local data and obtains an intermediate parameter θkisuperscriptsubscript𝜃𝑘𝑖\theta_{k}^{i}, where θki=wk−α​∇fi​(wk)superscriptsubscript𝜃𝑘𝑖subscript𝑤𝑘𝛼∇subscript𝑓𝑖subscript𝑤𝑘\theta_{k}^{i}=w_{k}-\alpha\nabla f_{i}(w_{k}). Then, with θkisuperscriptsubscript𝜃𝑘𝑖\theta_{k}^{i}, UE i𝑖i updates its local model using one or more steps of gradient descent and obtains wk+1isuperscriptsubscript𝑤𝑘1𝑖w_{k+1}^{i}. Such local model parameter updates are then sent to the server for model aggregation. The server will update the global model or meta model as wk+1subscript𝑤𝑘1w_{k+1}. This process repeats in the sequel rounds until a certain model accuracy is achieved or a predefined maximum number of rounds is reached.

Per-FedAvg is a MAML-based FL algorithm, which suggests a general approach to use the MAML method for solving the data heterogeneity problem in FL. It is proposed with focus on the personalization in FL, which is a natural feature inherited from MAML. Except for the personalization, MAML is also a few-shot learning approach, as only a few samples are required to learn new skills after just minutes of experience. Therefore, Per-FedAvg also inherits this feature of MAML, thereby adapting quickly from only a few samples. To what degree of fast adaptation MAML benefits FL and under what conditions such benefit can be achieved is what exactly this paper is about.

II-B Machine Learning Model

We consider the above described MAML-based FL. In detail, we concentrate on the situation where UEs communicate in a synchronous manner, so as to avoid using outdated parameters for global model update and make high-quality refinement in each round. Meanwhile, for each UE, we consider the case that only one step of stochastic gradient descent (SGD) is performed, following the same setting as [11].

As for the concerned MAML-based FL, our goal is to optimize the initial model using only a few data points at each UE. Hence, we only obtain an estimate of the desired gradient with SGD. Here, the desired gradient ∇Fi​(w)∇subscript𝐹𝑖𝑤\nabla F_{i}(w) on UE i𝑖i is computed using all data points in its dataset 𝒟isubscript𝒟𝑖\mathcal{D}_{i}, while the estimated gradient ∇~​Fi​(w)~∇subscript𝐹𝑖𝑤\tilde{\nabla}F_{i}(w) on UE i𝑖i is computed using SGD with the sampled dataset 𝒟i(⋅)∈𝒟isuperscriptsubscript𝒟𝑖⋅subscript𝒟𝑖\mathcal{D}_{i}^{(\cdot)}\in\mathcal{D}_{i}. Note that, the superscript (⋅)⋅(\cdot) represents different sampled datasets are used to estimate the involved gradients and Hessian in ∇Fi​(w)∇subscript𝐹𝑖𝑤\nabla F_{i}(w). Meanwhile, the sampled data size is Di(⋅)=|𝒟i(⋅)|superscriptsubscript𝐷𝑖⋅superscriptsubscript𝒟𝑖⋅D_{i}^{(\cdot)}=|\mathcal{D}_{i}^{(\cdot)}|.

More specifically, in order to solve (3), each UE i𝑖i computes the desired gradient in round k𝑘k, as follows:

∇Fi​(wk)=(I−α​∇2fi​(wk))​∇fi​(wk−α​∇fi​(wk)).∇subscript𝐹𝑖subscript𝑤𝑘𝐼𝛼superscript∇2subscript𝑓𝑖subscript𝑤𝑘∇subscript𝑓𝑖subscript𝑤𝑘𝛼∇subscript𝑓𝑖subscript𝑤𝑘\nabla F_{i}(w_{k})=(I-\alpha\nabla^{2}f_{i}(w_{k}))\nabla f_{i}(w_{k}-\alpha\nabla f_{i}(w_{k})). (5)

At every round, computing the gradient ∇fi​(wk)∇subscript𝑓𝑖subscript𝑤𝑘\nabla f_{i}(w_{k}) by using all data points of UE i𝑖i is often computationally expensive. Therefore, we take a subset 𝒟iinsuperscriptsubscript𝒟𝑖in\mathcal{D}_{i}^{\text{in}} from 𝒟isubscript𝒟𝑖\mathcal{D}_{i} to obtain an unbiased estimate ∇~​fi​(wk;𝒟iin)~∇subscript𝑓𝑖subscript𝑤𝑘superscriptsubscript𝒟𝑖in\tilde{\nabla}f_{i}(w_{k};\mathcal{D}_{i}^{\text{in}}) for ∇fi​(wk)∇subscript𝑓𝑖subscript𝑤𝑘\nabla f_{i}(w_{k}), which is given by

(6)

Similarly, the outer gradient update ∇fi​(θki)∇subscript𝑓𝑖superscriptsubscript𝜃𝑘𝑖\nabla f_{i}(\theta_{k}^{i}) and Hessian update ∇2fi​(wk)superscript∇2subscript𝑓𝑖subscript𝑤𝑘\nabla^{2}f_{i}(w_{k}) in (5) can be replaced by their unbiased estimates ∇~​fi​(θki;𝒟io)~∇subscript𝑓𝑖subscriptsuperscript𝜃𝑖𝑘superscriptsubscript𝒟𝑖o\tilde{\nabla}f_{i}(\theta^{i}_{k};\mathcal{D}_{i}^{\text{o}}) and ∇~2​fi​(wk;𝒟ih)superscript~∇2subscript𝑓𝑖subscript𝑤𝑘superscriptsubscript𝒟𝑖h\tilde{\nabla}^{2}f_{i}(w_{k};\mathcal{D}_{i}^{\text{h}}) respectively. Here, 𝒟iosuperscriptsubscript𝒟𝑖o\mathcal{D}_{i}^{\text{o}} and 𝒟ihsuperscriptsubscript𝒟𝑖h\mathcal{D}_{i}^{\text{h}} are sampled from 𝒟isubscript𝒟𝑖\mathcal{D}_{i} as well. (7)

It is worth noting that ∇~​Fi​(wk)~∇subscript𝐹𝑖subscript𝑤𝑘\tilde{\nabla}F_{i}(w_{k}) is a biased estimator of ∇Fi​(wk)∇subscript𝐹𝑖subscript𝑤𝑘\nabla F_{i}(w_{k}). This is because the stochastic gradient ∇~​fi​(wk−α​∇~​fi​(wk;𝒟iin);𝒟io)~∇subscript𝑓𝑖subscript𝑤𝑘𝛼~∇subscript𝑓𝑖subscript𝑤𝑘superscriptsubscript𝒟𝑖insuperscriptsubscript𝒟𝑖o\tilde{\nabla}f_{i}(w_{k}-\alpha\tilde{\nabla}f_{i}(w_{k};\mathcal{D}_{i}^{\text{in}});\mathcal{D}_{i}^{\text{o}}) contains another stochastic gradient ∇~​fi​(wk;𝒟iin)~∇subscript𝑓𝑖subscript𝑤𝑘superscriptsubscript𝒟𝑖in\tilde{\nabla}f_{i}(w_{k};\mathcal{D}_{i}^{\text{in}}) inside. Hence, to improve the estimate accuracy, 𝒟iinsuperscriptsubscript𝒟𝑖in\mathcal{D}_{i}^{\text{in}} used for inner gradient update is independent from the sampled datasets 𝒟iosuperscriptsubscript𝒟𝑖o\mathcal{D}_{i}^{\text{o}} and 𝒟ihsuperscriptsubscript𝒟𝑖h\mathcal{D}_{i}^{\text{h}} used for outer gradient and Hessian update respectively. Meanwhile, in this paper we assume 𝒟iosuperscriptsubscript𝒟𝑖o\mathcal{D}_{i}^{\text{o}} and 𝒟ihsuperscriptsubscript𝒟𝑖h\mathcal{D}_{i}^{\text{h}} are also independent from each other.

II-C Communication and Computation Model

When exploring the MAML-based FL in realistic mobile edge networks, the communication and computation model should be captured carefully. Particularly, we consider that UEs access the BS through a channel partitioning scheme, such as orthogonal frequency division multiple access (OFDMA). In order to successfully upload the local update to the BS, two conditions need to be satisfied: (1) the UE is selected, and (2) the transmitted local update is successfully decoded. In this respect, we first introduce sik∈{0,1}superscriptsubscript𝑠𝑖𝑘01s_{i}^{k}\in\{0,1\} as a selection indicator, where ski=1superscriptsubscript𝑠𝑘𝑖1s_{k}^{i}=1 indicates the event that UE i𝑖i is chosen in round k𝑘k, and ski=0superscriptsubscript𝑠𝑘𝑖0s_{k}^{i}=0 otherwise. Next, we characterize the transmission quality of the wireless links. For the signals transmitted from UE i𝑖i, the SNR received at the BS can be expressed as ξki=pki​hki​‖ci‖−κN0superscriptsubscript𝜉𝑘𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑝𝑘𝑖superscriptsubscriptℎ𝑘𝑖superscriptnormsubscript𝑐𝑖𝜅subscript𝑁0\xi_{k}^{i}=\frac{p_{k}^{i}h_{k}^{i}\|c_{i}\|^{-\kappa}}{N_{0}}, where pkisuperscriptsubscript𝑝𝑘𝑖p_{k}^{i} is the transmit power of UE i𝑖i during round k𝑘k, κ𝜅\kappa is the path loss exponent. hki​‖ci‖−κsuperscriptsubscriptℎ𝑘𝑖superscriptnormsubscript𝑐𝑖𝜅h_{k}^{i}\|c_{i}\|^{-\kappa} is the channel gain between UE i𝑖i and the BS with cisubscript𝑐𝑖c_{i} being the distance between UE i𝑖i and the BS and hkisuperscriptsubscriptℎ𝑘𝑖h_{k}^{i} being the small-scale channel coefficient. N0subscript𝑁0N_{0} is the noise power spectral density. In order for the BS to successfully decode the local update from UE i𝑖i, it is required that the received SNR exceeds a decoding threshold ϕitalic-ϕ\phi, i.e., ξki>ϕsuperscriptsubscript𝜉𝑘𝑖italic-ϕ\xi_{k}^{i}>\phi. Assume that the small-scale channel coefficients across communication rounds follow Rayleigh distribution, then according to [22], the update success transmission probability, defined as qki=ℙ​(ski=1,ξki>ϕ)superscriptsubscript𝑞𝑘𝑖ℙformulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscript𝑠𝑘𝑖1superscriptsubscript𝜉𝑘𝑖italic-ϕq_{k}^{i}=\mathbb{P}(s_{k}^{i}=1,\xi_{k}^{i}>\phi), can be estimated as follows:

qki=ℙ​(ski=1,ξki>ϕ)≈1/n1+ν​(pki).superscriptsubscript𝑞𝑘𝑖ℙformulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscript𝑠𝑘𝑖1superscriptsubscript𝜉𝑘𝑖italic-ϕ1𝑛1𝜈superscriptsubscript𝑝𝑘𝑖q_{k}^{i}=\mathbb{P}(s_{k}^{i}=1,\xi_{k}^{i}>\phi)\approx\frac{1/n}{1+\nu(p_{k}^{i})}. (8)

where ν​(pki)=N0​ϕpki𝜈superscriptsubscript𝑝𝑘𝑖subscript𝑁0italic-ϕsuperscriptsubscript𝑝𝑘𝑖\nu(p_{k}^{i})=\frac{N_{0}\phi}{p_{k}^{i}}. Then the achievable uplink rate rk,isubscript𝑟𝑘𝑖r_{k,i} of UE i𝑖i transmitting its local update to the BS in round k𝑘k is given by

rk,i=B​log2⁡(1+ξki),subscript𝑟𝑘𝑖𝐵subscript21superscriptsubscript𝜉𝑘𝑖r_{k,i}=B\log_{2}(1+\xi_{k}^{i}), (9)

where B𝐵B is the bandwidth allocated to each UE. Based on rk,isubscript𝑟𝑘𝑖r_{k,i}, the uplink transmission delay of UE i𝑖i in round k𝑘k can be specified as follows:

tk,icom=Zrk,i,superscriptsubscript𝑡𝑘𝑖com𝑍subscript𝑟𝑘𝑖t_{k,i}^{\text{com}}=\frac{Z}{r_{k,i}}, (10)

where Z𝑍Z is the size of wksubscript𝑤𝑘w_{k} in number of bits. Since the transmit power of the BS is much higher than that of the UEs, the downlink transmission delay is much smaller than the uplink transmission delay. Meanwhile, we care more about the transmit power allocation on individual UEs rather than that on the BS, so here we ignore the downlink transmission delay for simplicity.

Further, we calculate the computation time for each UE, which is consumed for computing the local update. Given the CPU-cycle frequency of UE i𝑖i by ϑisubscriptitalic-ϑ𝑖\vartheta_{i}, the computation time of UE i𝑖i is expressed as

tk,icmp=ci​dkiϑi.superscriptsubscript𝑡𝑘𝑖cmpsubscript𝑐𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑑𝑘𝑖subscriptitalic-ϑ𝑖t_{k,i}^{\text{cmp}}=\frac{c_{i}d_{k}^{i}}{\vartheta_{i}}. (11)

In (11), cisubscript𝑐𝑖c_{i} denotes the number of CPU cycles for UE i𝑖i to execute one sample of data points and dki=Dk,iin+Dk,io+Dk,ihsuperscriptsubscript𝑑𝑘𝑖superscriptsubscript𝐷𝑘𝑖insuperscriptsubscript𝐷𝑘𝑖osuperscriptsubscript𝐷𝑘𝑖hd_{k}^{i}=D_{k,i}^{\text{in}}+D_{k,i}^{\text{o}}+D_{k,i}^{\text{h}} denotes the sampled data size of UE i𝑖i in round k𝑘k.

In term of tk,icomsuperscriptsubscript𝑡𝑘𝑖comt_{k,i}^{\text{com}} and tk,icmpsuperscriptsubscript𝑡𝑘𝑖cmpt_{k,i}^{\text{cmp}}, we then give the energy consumption of each UE i𝑖i in round k𝑘k, which consists of two parts: (1) the energy for transmitting the local updates and (2) the energy for computing the local updates. Let ekisuperscriptsubscript𝑒𝑘𝑖e_{k}^{i} denote the energy consumption of each UE i𝑖i in round k𝑘k, and then ekisuperscriptsubscript𝑒𝑘𝑖e_{k}^{i} can be computed as follows [23, 24]:

eki=ς2​ϑi3​tk,icmp+pki​tk,icom,superscriptsubscript𝑒𝑘𝑖𝜍2superscriptsubscriptitalic-ϑ𝑖3superscriptsubscript𝑡𝑘𝑖cmpsuperscriptsubscript𝑝𝑘𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑡𝑘𝑖come_{k}^{i}=\frac{\varsigma}{2}\vartheta_{i}^{3}t_{k,i}^{\text{cmp}}+p_{k}^{i}t_{k,i}^{\text{com}}, (12)

where ς2𝜍2\frac{\varsigma}{2} is the effective capacitance coefficient of UE i𝑖i’s computing chipset. From (12), we observe that in round k𝑘k for each UE i𝑖i, both the sampled data size diksuperscriptsubscript𝑑𝑖𝑘d_{i}^{k} and transmit power piksuperscriptsubscript𝑝𝑖𝑘p_{i}^{k} have significant impacts on its energy consumption. This observation motivates us to jointly consider these two variables when quantifying the benefit MAML brings to FL in mobile edge networks.

II-D Problem Formulation

In order to quantify the benefit MAML brings to FL in mobile edge networks, we focus on the learning time minimization under the constraint of model accuracy and UEs’ energy consumption. Particularly, the learning time is the duration over all K𝐾K communication rounds, in which the duration of round k𝑘k is determined by the slowest UE as follows,

Tkround=maxi∈𝒜k⁡{tk,icmp+tk,icom}.superscriptsubscript𝑇𝑘roundsubscript𝑖subscript𝒜𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑡𝑘𝑖cmpsuperscriptsubscript𝑡𝑘𝑖comT_{k}^{\text{round}}=\max_{i\in\mathcal{A}_{k}}\{t_{k,i}^{\text{cmp}}+t_{k,i}^{\text{com}}\}. (13)

Note that we can replace i∈𝒜k𝑖subscript𝒜𝑘i\in\mathcal{A}_{k} with i∈𝒰𝑖𝒰i\in\mathcal{U} in Tkroundsuperscriptsubscript𝑇𝑘roundT_{k}^{\text{round}}, that is, Tkround=maxi∈𝒰⁡{tk,icmp+tk,icom}superscriptsubscript𝑇𝑘roundsubscript𝑖𝒰superscriptsubscript𝑡𝑘𝑖cmpsuperscriptsubscript𝑡𝑘𝑖comT_{k}^{\text{round}}=\max_{i\in\mathcal{U}}\{t_{k,i}^{\text{cmp}}+t_{k,i}^{\text{com}}\}. This is because the UEs that are not chosen in 𝒜ksubscript𝒜𝑘\mathcal{A}_{k} has a Tkisuperscriptsubscript𝑇𝑘𝑖T_{k}^{i} with the value of 00, which would not effect the result of Tkroundsuperscriptsubscript𝑇𝑘roundT_{k}^{\text{round}}. Let 𝐝≜{𝐝1,…,𝐝n}≜𝐝superscript𝐝1…superscript𝐝𝑛\mathbf{d}\triangleq\{\mathbf{d}^{1},\dots,\mathbf{d}^{n}\} and 𝐩≜{𝐩1,…,𝐩n}≜𝐩superscript𝐩1…superscript𝐩𝑛\mathbf{p}\triangleq\{\mathbf{p}^{1},\dots,\mathbf{p}^{n}\} denote the UEs’ sampled data size vector and the transmit power vector respectively, where 𝐝i≜{d1i,…,dKi}≜superscript𝐝𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑑1𝑖…superscriptsubscript𝑑𝐾𝑖\mathbf{d}^{i}\triangleq\{d_{1}^{i},\dots,d_{K}^{i}\} and 𝐩i≜{p1i,…,pKi}≜superscript𝐩𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑝1𝑖…superscriptsubscript𝑝𝐾𝑖\mathbf{p}^{i}\triangleq\{p_{1}^{i},\dots,p_{K}^{i}\}. Then, we can give the problem formulation by

min𝐝,𝐩,Ksubscript𝐝𝐩𝐾\displaystyle\min_{\mathbf{d},\mathbf{p},K}\qquad ∑k=0K−1maxi∈𝒰⁡{tk,icmp+tk,icom}superscriptsubscript𝑘0𝐾1subscript𝑖𝒰superscriptsubscript𝑡𝑘𝑖cmpsuperscriptsubscript𝑡𝑘𝑖com\displaystyle\sum_{k=0}^{K-1}\max_{i\in\mathcal{U}}\{t_{k,i}^{\text{cmp}}+t_{k,i}^{\text{com}}\} (P1)
s.t. 1K​∑k=0K−1𝔼​[‖∇F​(wk)‖2]≤ϵ,1𝐾superscriptsubscript𝑘0𝐾1𝔼delimited-[]superscriptnorm∇𝐹subscript𝑤𝑘2italic-ϵ\displaystyle\frac{1}{K}\sum_{k=0}^{K-1}\mathbb{E}[\|\nabla F(w_{k})\|^{2}]\leq\epsilon, (C1.1)
0≤eki≤Emax,∀i∈𝒰,k=0,…,K−1formulae-sequence0superscriptsubscript𝑒𝑘𝑖subscript𝐸formulae-sequencefor-all𝑖𝒰𝑘0…𝐾1\displaystyle 0\leq e_{k}^{i}\leq E_{\max},\quad\forall i\in\mathcal{U},k=0,...,K-1 (C1.2)
0≤pki≤Pmax,∀i∈𝒰,k=0,…,K−1formulae-sequence0superscriptsubscript𝑝𝑘𝑖subscript𝑃formulae-sequencefor-all𝑖𝒰𝑘0…𝐾1\displaystyle 0\leq p_{k}^{i}\leq P_{\max},\quad\forall i\in\mathcal{U},k=0,...,K-1 (C1.3)
0≤dki≤Di,∀i∈𝒰,k=0,…,K−1.formulae-sequence0superscriptsubscript𝑑𝑘𝑖subscript𝐷𝑖formulae-sequencefor-all𝑖𝒰𝑘0…𝐾1\displaystyle 0\leq d_{k}^{i}\leq D_{i},\quad\forall i\in\mathcal{U},k=0,...,K-1. (C1.4)

In problem (P1), we not only optimize 𝐝𝐝\mathbf{d} and 𝐩𝐩\mathbf{p}, but also the total number of rounds K𝐾K. The hidden reason is that, both 𝐝𝐝\mathbf{d} and 𝐩𝐩\mathbf{p} have an effect on the duration of each round, thereby impacting the number of rounds K𝐾K to achieve a certain model accuracy ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon. Besides, (C1.1) characterizes an ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon-approximate convergence performance. (C1.2) limits the energy consumption of UE i𝑖i in round k𝑘k not larger the predefined maximum value Emaxsubscript𝐸E_{\max}. (C1.3) gives the maximum transmit power of UE i𝑖i in round k𝑘k by Pmaxsubscript𝑃P_{\max}. (C1.4) is the sampled data size constraint, that the sampled data size of one UE in round k𝑘k is smaller than or equal to the data points generated by that UE. The solution to problem (P1) can be exploited for designing an optimized MAML-based FL algorithm, which is implemented iteratively to update the global model parameter w𝑤w. According to the communication and computation model, only those local updates from the selected UEs as well as being successfully decoded by the BS can contribute to updating the global model parameter. That is, in round k𝑘k, we have

wk+1=subscript𝑤𝑘1absent\displaystyle w_{k+1}= 1∑i=1n𝟙​{ski=1,ξki>ϕ}1superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛1formulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscript𝑠𝑘𝑖1superscriptsubscript𝜉𝑘𝑖italic-ϕ\displaystyle\frac{1}{\sum_{i=1}^{n}\mathds{1}\{s_{k}^{i}=1,\xi_{k}^{i}>\phi\}}
∑i=1n𝟙​{ski=1,ξki≥ϕ}​(wk−β​∇wkF​(θki)),superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛1formulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscript𝑠𝑘𝑖1superscriptsubscript𝜉𝑘𝑖italic-ϕsubscript𝑤𝑘𝛽subscript∇subscript𝑤𝑘𝐹superscriptsubscript𝜃𝑘𝑖\displaystyle\sum_{i=1}^{n}\mathds{1}\{s_{k}^{i}=1,\xi_{k}^{i}\geq\phi\}(w_{k}-\beta\nabla_{w_{k}}F(\theta_{k}^{i})), (15)

where 𝟙​{ski=1,γki>ϕ}=11formulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscript𝑠𝑘𝑖1superscriptsubscript𝛾𝑘𝑖italic-ϕ1\mathds{1}\{s_{k}^{i}=1,\gamma_{k}^{i}>\phi\}=1 if the event of ski=1,γki>ϕformulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscript𝑠𝑘𝑖1superscriptsubscript𝛾𝑘𝑖italic-ϕs_{k}^{i}=1,\gamma_{k}^{i}>\phi is true, and it equals to zero otherwise.

Based on this update rule, (C1.1) related to the MAML-based FL can be analytically analysed to make the relationship between the decision variables and the model accuracy ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon explicit, thereby facilitating solving problem (P1). In this regard, the convergence analysis of the MAML-based FL is given in the following section.

III Convergence Analysis of MAML-based FL

III-A Preliminaries

For a general purpose, we concentrate on the non-convex settings on loss functions and aim to find an ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon-approximate first-order stationary point (FOSP) for the loss function minimization problem (3) in the MAML-based FL, which is defined as follows.

Definition 1.

A random vector wϵ∈ℝmsubscript𝑤italic-ϵsuperscriptℝ𝑚w_{\epsilon}\in\mathbb{R}^{m} is called an ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon-FOSP if it satisfies 𝔼​[‖∇F​(wϵ)‖2]≤ϵ𝔼delimited-[]superscriptnorm∇𝐹subscript𝑤italic-ϵ2italic-ϵ\mathbb{E}[\|\nabla F(w_{\epsilon})\|^{2}]\leq\epsilon.

In terms of this Definition, we then elaborate on the assumptions, convergence bounds, and discussions on the convergence analysis, respectively, from which we can reformulate (C1.1) in problem (P1) as an explicit constraint with respect to the optimization variables.

Without loss of generality, the assumptions used for the convergence analysis of MAML-based FL algorithm is consistent with that of Per-FedAvg [21, 14] and are given in the following.

Assumption 1.

For every UE i∈{1,…,n}𝑖1…𝑛i\in\{1,\dots,n\}, fi​(w)subscript𝑓𝑖𝑤f_{i}(w) is twice continuously differentiable. Its gradient ∇fi​(w)∇subscript𝑓𝑖𝑤\nabla f_{i}(w) is L𝐿L-Lipschitz continuous, that is,

‖∇fi​(w)−∇fi​(u)‖≤L​‖w−u‖,∀w,u∈ℝm.formulae-sequencenorm∇subscript𝑓𝑖𝑤∇subscript𝑓𝑖𝑢𝐿norm𝑤𝑢for-all𝑤𝑢superscriptℝ𝑚\|\nabla f_{i}(w)-\nabla f_{i}(u)\|\leq L\|w-u\|,\qquad\forall w,u\in\mathbb{R}^{m}. (16)

‖∇2fi​(w)−∇2fi​(u)‖≤ρ​‖w−u‖,∀w,u∈ℝm.formulae-sequencenormsuperscript∇2subscript𝑓𝑖𝑤superscript∇2subscript𝑓𝑖𝑢𝜌norm𝑤𝑢for-all𝑤𝑢superscriptℝ𝑚\|\nabla^{2}f_{i}(w)-\nabla^{2}f_{i}(u)\|\leq\rho\|w-u\|,\qquad\forall w,u\in\mathbb{R}^{m}. (17)

III-B Analysis of Convergence Bound

Let Ui=maxk={1,…,K}⁡Ukisubscript𝑈𝑖subscript𝑘1…𝐾superscriptsubscript𝑈𝑘𝑖U_{i}=\max_{k=\{1,\dots,K\}}U_{k}^{i}, where Uki=ℙ​{ski=1,ξki>ϕ}∑i=1nℙ​{ski=1,ξki>ϕ}=qki∑i=1nqkisuperscriptsubscript𝑈𝑘𝑖ℙformulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscript𝑠𝑘𝑖1superscriptsubscript𝜉𝑘𝑖italic-ϕsuperscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛ℙformulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscript𝑠𝑘𝑖1superscriptsubscript𝜉𝑘𝑖italic-ϕsuperscriptsubscript𝑞𝑘𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑞𝑘𝑖U_{k}^{i}=\frac{\mathbb{P}\{s_{k}^{i}=1,\xi_{k}^{i}>\phi\}}{\sum_{i=1}^{n}\mathbb{P}\{s_{k}^{i}=1,\xi_{k}^{i}>\phi\}}=\frac{q_{k}^{i}}{\sum_{i=1}^{n}q_{k}^{i}} denotes the normalized update successful probability of UE i𝑖i in round k𝑘k. Then, with Lemmas 1, 2 and 3, the expected convergence result of the MAML-based FL within a general mobile edge network we describe in Section II can now be obtained by the following theorem.

Theorem 1.

Given the transmit power vector 𝐩𝐩\mathbf{p}, the sampled data size vector 𝐝𝐝\mathbf{d}, the number of communication rounds K𝐾K, and the optimal global loss F​(wϵ)𝐹subscript𝑤italic-ϵF(w_{\epsilon}), the normalized update successful probability Uisubscript𝑈𝑖U_{i}, and α∈(0,1/L]𝛼01𝐿\alpha\in(0,1/L], then we have the following FOSP conditions,

w¯k=1∑i=1n𝟙​{ski=1,ξki>ϕ}​∑i=1n𝟙​{ski=1,ξki>ϕ}​wki.subscript¯𝑤𝑘1superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛1formulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscript𝑠𝑘𝑖1superscriptsubscript𝜉𝑘𝑖italic-ϕsuperscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛1formulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscript𝑠𝑘𝑖1superscriptsubscript𝜉𝑘𝑖italic-ϕsuperscriptsubscript𝑤𝑘𝑖\bar{w}_{k}=\frac{1}{\sum_{i=1}^{n}\mathds{1}\{s_{k}^{i}=1,\xi_{k}^{i}>\phi\}}\sum_{i=1}^{n}\mathds{1}\{s_{k}^{i}=1,\xi_{k}^{i}>\phi\}w_{k}^{i}. (26)
Proof:

See the Appendix. ∎

Unlike the convergence guarantee of Per-FedAvg in [14] which is characterized by K𝐾K and 𝐝𝐝\mathbf{d}, the convergence guarantee obtained from Theorem 1 is characterized by K𝐾K, 𝐝𝐝\mathbf{d} and Uisubscript𝑈𝑖U_{i}, where Uisubscript𝑈𝑖U_{i} is a function of the transmit power 𝐩isuperscript𝐩𝑖\mathbf{p}^{i}. That is, the convergence bound of the proposed MAML-based FL in our paper is described in terms of K𝐾K, 𝐝𝐝\mathbf{d} and 𝐩𝐩\mathbf{p}. Therefore, our convergence analysis can combine the FL hyperparameters as well as the resource allocation in mobile edge networks.

III-C Discussions

From Theorem 1, we are able to characterize K𝐾K, 𝐝𝐝\mathbf{d} and 𝐩𝐩\mathbf{p} with respect to the predefined model accuracy ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon. According to Theorem 1 and (C1.1) in problem (P1), it is desired for the right-hand-side of (1) to be equal to or smaller than ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon. Consequently, we further present the following corollary.

Corollary 1.

Suppose the conditions in Theorem 1 are satisfied. If we set the number of total communication rounds as K=𝒪​(1ϵ3)𝐾𝒪1superscriptitalic-ϵ3K=\mathcal{O}(\frac{1}{\epsilon^{3}}), the global learning rate as β=𝒪​(ϵ2)𝛽𝒪superscriptitalic-ϵ2\beta=\mathcal{O}(\epsilon^{2}), the number of data samples as di=𝒪​(1ϵ)subscript𝑑𝑖𝒪1italic-ϵd_{i}=\mathcal{O}(\frac{1}{\epsilon}), then we find an ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon-FOSP for the MAML-based FL in problem (P1).

Proof:

K=𝒪​(1ϵ3)𝐾𝒪1superscriptitalic-ϵ3K=\mathcal{O}(\frac{1}{\epsilon^{3}}) and β=𝒪​(ϵ2)𝛽𝒪superscriptitalic-ϵ2\beta=\mathcal{O}(\epsilon^{2}) will make sure that the order of magnitude of the first term on the right-hand-side of (1) to be equal to 𝒪​(ϵ)𝒪italic-ϵ\mathcal{O}(\epsilon).

Then we examine the second term. Since Uisubscript𝑈𝑖U_{i} is the normalized update successful probability with the consideration of n𝑛n UEs, its order of magnitude is defined by n𝑛n rather than ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon, i.e., Ui=𝒪​(1n)subscript𝑈𝑖𝒪1𝑛U_{i}=\mathcal{O}(\frac{1}{n}). Therefore, it is natural to take attentions on the term β​LF​σF2+β​LF​γF2+α2​L2​σG2Din𝛽subscript𝐿𝐹superscriptsubscript𝜎𝐹2𝛽subscript𝐿𝐹superscriptsubscript𝛾𝐹2superscript𝛼2superscript𝐿2superscriptsubscript𝜎𝐺2superscript𝐷in\beta L_{F}\sigma_{F}^{2}+\beta L_{F}\gamma_{F}^{2}+\frac{\alpha^{2}L^{2}\sigma_{G}^{2}}{D^{\text{in}}} for an ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon-FOSP. By setting Diin=Dio=Dih=𝒪​(1ϵ)superscriptsubscript𝐷𝑖insuperscriptsubscript𝐷𝑖osuperscriptsubscript𝐷𝑖h𝒪1italic-ϵD_{i}^{\text{in}}=D_{i}^{\text{o}}=D_{i}^{\text{h}}=\mathcal{O}(\frac{1}{\epsilon}) (i.e., di=𝒪​(1ϵ)subscript𝑑𝑖𝒪1italic-ϵd_{i}=\mathcal{O}(\frac{1}{\epsilon})), α2​L2​σG2Dinsuperscript𝛼2superscript𝐿2superscriptsubscript𝜎𝐺2superscript𝐷in\frac{\alpha^{2}L^{2}\sigma_{G}^{2}}{D^{\text{in}}} will dominate the value of β​LF​σF2+β​LF​γF2+α2​L2​σG2Din𝛽subscript𝐿𝐹superscriptsubscript𝜎𝐹2𝛽subscript𝐿𝐹superscriptsubscript𝛾𝐹2superscript𝛼2superscript𝐿2superscriptsubscript𝜎𝐺2superscript𝐷in\beta L_{F}\sigma_{F}^{2}+\beta L_{F}\gamma_{F}^{2}+\frac{\alpha^{2}L^{2}\sigma_{G}^{2}}{D^{\text{in}}}. This is because, in this case, β​LF​σF2+β​LF​γF2=𝒪​(ϵ4)𝛽subscript𝐿𝐹superscriptsubscript𝜎𝐹2𝛽subscript𝐿𝐹superscriptsubscript𝛾𝐹2𝒪superscriptitalic-ϵ4\beta L_{F}\sigma_{F}^{2}+\beta L_{F}\gamma_{F}^{2}=\mathcal{O}(\epsilon^{4}), which is a high-order infinitesimal of ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon. Finally, combining the magnitudes of the first and second terms, we can conclude that the joint of K=𝒪​(1ϵ3)𝐾𝒪1superscriptitalic-ϵ3K=\mathcal{O}(\frac{1}{\epsilon^{3}}), β=𝒪​(ϵ2)𝛽𝒪superscriptitalic-ϵ2\beta=\mathcal{O}(\epsilon^{2}), and di=𝒪​(1ϵ)subscript𝑑𝑖𝒪1italic-ϵd_{i}=\mathcal{O}(\frac{1}{\epsilon}) yields an ϵitalic-ϵ\mathcal{\epsilon}-FOSP for the MAML-based FL. ∎

Remark 1.

It is worth noting that the result in Corollary 1 provides a possible choice of the hyperparameters. Other options may also be valid as long as the option makes the order of magnitude of the hyperparamters (w.r.t. the model accuracy ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon) satisfy the condition in Theorem 1.

Guided by Corollary 1, we can recast (C1.1) in problem (P1) as a series of constraints, which give explicit relationships between optimization variables and the model accuracy ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon. In this way, we then solve problem (P1) with high efficiency in the next section.

IV Automated Federated Learning (AutoFL)

In this section, we first resort to Theorem 1 and Corollary 1 for problem (P1) decomposition, and then solve the resultant subproblems respectively. Based on the obtained solutions, we finally propose Automated Federated Learning (AutoFL) algorithm, by which the benefit MAML brings to FL can be quantified in mobile edge networks.

IV-A Problem Decoupling

The clue to the decomposition of problem (P1) follows the primal decomposition [25]. Specifically, the master problem is optimized with respect to the number of communication rounds K𝐾K, which is given as follows:

minKsubscript𝐾\displaystyle\min_{K}\qquad ∑k=0K−1maxi∈𝒰⁡{tk,icmp+tk,icom}superscriptsubscript𝑘0𝐾1subscript𝑖𝒰superscriptsubscript𝑡𝑘𝑖cmpsuperscriptsubscript𝑡𝑘𝑖com\displaystyle\sum_{k=0}^{K-1}\max_{i\in\mathcal{U}}\{t_{k,i}^{\text{cmp}}+t_{k,i}^{\text{com}}\} (P2)
s.t. 4​(F​(w0)−F​(wϵ))β​K≤ϵ,K∈ℕ+.formulae-sequence4𝐹subscript𝑤0𝐹subscript𝑤italic-ϵ𝛽𝐾italic-ϵ𝐾superscriptℕ\displaystyle\frac{4(F(w_{0})-F(w_{\epsilon}))}{\beta K}\leq\epsilon,\qquad K\in\mathbb{N}^{+}. (C2.1)

Note that, we refer to Theorem 1 and use a contracted (C1.1), i.e., (C2.1), as the constraint in problem (P2) for tractability. This contraction replaces 1K​∑k=0K−1𝔼​[‖∇F​(w¯k)‖2]1𝐾superscriptsubscript𝑘0𝐾1𝔼delimited-[]superscriptnorm∇𝐹subscript¯𝑤𝑘2\frac{1}{K}\sum_{k=0}^{K-1}\mathbb{E}[\|\nabla F(\bar{w}_{k})\|^{2}] with its upper bound without the second term. The reason that we get rid of the second term is that we only consider K𝐾K as the decision variable in (P2), and the second term of the upper bound can be regarded as a constant and thus removed as long as its value is no larger than ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon. Meanwhile, the above contraction shrinks the feasible region of K𝐾K. Therefore, as long as (C2.1) is satisfied, (C1.1) must be satisfied. Moreover, if there exists an optimal solution K𝐾K to problem (P2), it is also feasible to the original problem (P1). We can regard the optimal solution to (P2) as an optimal approximation to (P1).

The reason that we consider K𝐾K as a decision variable is for the decoupling of (P1). The original objective of minimizing the overall learning time in K𝐾K rounds can be regarded as the minimization of the learning time in each round, once K𝐾K is determined and is set to be a constant in the following decoupling. As such, problem (P2), which has a slave problem with respect to the sampled data size 𝐝𝐝\mathbf{d} and transmit power 𝐩𝐩\mathbf{p}, can be regarded as an approximation of problem (P1).

From Theorem 1, we find that 𝐝𝐝\mathbf{d} and 𝐩𝐩\mathbf{p} are coupled even though (C1.1) is replaced by the right-hand-side term in (1). In this regard, we aim to optimize 𝐝𝐝\mathbf{d} and 𝐩𝐩\mathbf{p} in the slave problem with the coordinate descent [20] method. That is, the slave problem is firstly solved with 𝐝𝐝\mathbf{d} as variables and 𝐩𝐩\mathbf{p} as constants, and then is solved with 𝐩𝐩\mathbf{p} as variables and 𝐝𝐝\mathbf{d} as constants. This procedure is repeated in an iterative manner. In this way, 𝐝𝐝\mathbf{d}- and 𝐩𝐩\mathbf{p}-related slave problems can be further decomposed among rounds under the assistance of Corollary 1. Specifically, in any round k𝑘k, the sampled data size for UE i𝑖i is optimized by solving problem (P3):

mindkisubscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝑑𝑘𝑖\displaystyle\min_{d_{k}^{i}}\qquad maxi{ciϑi​dki+tk,icom}subscript𝑖subscript𝑐𝑖subscriptitalic-ϑ𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑑𝑘𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑡𝑘𝑖com\displaystyle\max_{i}\quad\left\{\frac{c_{i}}{\vartheta_{i}}d_{k}^{i}+t_{k,i}^{\text{com}}\right\} (P3)
s.t. dki≥1ϵ,∀i∈𝒰,formulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscript𝑑𝑘𝑖1italic-ϵfor-all𝑖𝒰\displaystyle d_{k}^{i}\geq\frac{1}{\epsilon},\quad\forall i\in\mathcal{U}, (C3.1)
ς2​ci​dki​ϑi2+pki​ZB​log2⁡(1+ξki)≤Emax,∀i∈𝒰,formulae-sequence𝜍2subscript𝑐𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑑𝑘𝑖superscriptsubscriptitalic-ϑ𝑖2superscriptsubscript𝑝𝑘𝑖𝑍𝐵subscript21superscriptsubscript𝜉𝑘𝑖subscript𝐸for-all𝑖𝒰\displaystyle\frac{\varsigma}{2}c_{i}d_{k}^{i}\vartheta_{i}^{2}+p_{k}^{i}\frac{Z}{B\log_{2}(1+\xi_{k}^{i})}\leq E_{\max},\quad\forall i\in\mathcal{U}, (C3.2)
0≤dki≤Di,∀i∈𝒰.formulae-sequence0superscriptsubscript𝑑𝑘𝑖subscript𝐷𝑖for-all𝑖𝒰\displaystyle 0\leq d_{k}^{i}\leq D_{i},\quad\forall i\in\mathcal{U}. (C3.3)

(C3.1) is obtained from Corollary 1, that a di=𝒪​(1ϵ)subscript𝑑𝑖𝒪1italic-ϵd_{i}=\mathcal{O}(\frac{1}{\epsilon}) will yield an ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon-FOSP. (C3.1) uses dki≥1ϵsuperscriptsubscript𝑑𝑘𝑖1italic-ϵd_{k}^{i}\geq\frac{1}{\epsilon} instead to indicate that as long as dkisuperscriptsubscript𝑑𝑘𝑖d_{k}^{i} is not smaller than 1ϵ1italic-ϵ\frac{1}{\epsilon}, an ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon-FOSP would be guaranteed. This is a reasonable replacement (i.e., from dki=𝒪​(1ϵ)superscriptsubscript𝑑𝑘𝑖𝒪1italic-ϵd_{k}^{i}=\mathcal{O}(\frac{1}{\epsilon}) to dki≥1ϵsuperscriptsubscript𝑑𝑘𝑖1italic-ϵd_{k}^{i}\geq\frac{1}{\epsilon}) such that, the larger the sampled data size is, the larger accuracy AutoFL would achieve, thereby leading to a smaller ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon. Note that (C3.1) is also a contraction of (C1.1), and the feasible domain of dkisuperscriptsubscript𝑑𝑘𝑖d_{k}^{i} is also shrunk. That is, the optimal dki⁣∗superscriptsubscript𝑑𝑘𝑖d_{k}^{i*}, as long as it exists in (P3), is also feasible in problem (P1), and can be regarded as an optimal approximation to (P1). (C3.2) is the energy consumption constraint on each UE and (C3.3) indicates that the sampled data size of UE i𝑖i is no greater than the number of data points generated by UE i𝑖i. Furthermore, addressing the following problem can make an decision on the transmit power of UE i𝑖i in round k𝑘k:

minpkisubscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝑝𝑘𝑖\displaystyle\min_{p_{k}^{i}}\qquad maxi{tk,icmp+ZB​log2⁡(1+ξki)}subscript𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑡𝑘𝑖cmp𝑍𝐵subscript21superscriptsubscript𝜉𝑘𝑖\displaystyle\max_{i}\quad\left\{t_{k,i}^{\text{cmp}}+\frac{Z}{B\log_{2}(1+\xi_{k}^{i})}\right\} (P4)
s.t. (∑i=1nUki2)​α2​L2​σG2Din≤ϵ,superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛superscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝑈𝑘𝑖2superscript𝛼2superscript𝐿2superscriptsubscript𝜎𝐺2superscript𝐷initalic-ϵ\displaystyle\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n}{U_{k}^{i}}^{2}\right)\frac{\alpha^{2}L^{2}\sigma_{G}^{2}}{D^{\text{in}}}\leq\epsilon, (C4.1)
ς2​ci​dki​ϑi2+pki​ZB​log2⁡(1+ξki)≤Emax,∀i∈𝒰,formulae-sequence𝜍2subscript𝑐𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑑𝑘𝑖superscriptsubscriptitalic-ϑ𝑖2superscriptsubscript𝑝𝑘𝑖𝑍𝐵subscript21superscriptsubscript𝜉𝑘𝑖subscript𝐸for-all𝑖𝒰\displaystyle\frac{\varsigma}{2}c_{i}d_{k}^{i}\vartheta_{i}^{2}+p_{k}^{i}\frac{Z}{B\log_{2}(1+\xi_{k}^{i})}\leq E_{\max},\quad\forall i\in\mathcal{U}, (C4.2)
0≤pki≤Pmax,∀i∈𝒰,formulae-sequence0superscriptsubscript𝑝𝑘𝑖subscript𝑃for-all𝑖𝒰\displaystyle 0\leq p_{k}^{i}\leq P_{\max},\quad\forall i\in\mathcal{U}, (C4.3)

where (C4.1) is obtained from Corollary 1, in terms of the fact that (∑i=1nUki2)​α2​L2​σG2Dinsuperscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛superscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝑈𝑘𝑖2superscript𝛼2superscript𝐿2superscriptsubscript𝜎𝐺2superscript𝐷in(\sum_{i=1}^{n}{U_{k}^{i}}^{2})\frac{\alpha^{2}L^{2}\sigma_{G}^{2}}{D^{\text{in}}} dominates the value of the second term in the right-hand-side of (1) to guarantee an ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon-FOSP for the MAML-based FL. Here we replace Uisubscript𝑈𝑖U_{i} with Ukisuperscriptsubscript𝑈𝑘𝑖U_{k}^{i} to show that in each round k𝑘k, (C4.1) should be satisfied. The reason that we replace (∑i=1nUki2)​α2​L2​σG2Din=𝒪​(1ϵ)superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛superscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝑈𝑘𝑖2superscript𝛼2superscript𝐿2superscriptsubscript𝜎𝐺2superscript𝐷in𝒪1italic-ϵ(\sum_{i=1}^{n}{U_{k}^{i}}^{2})\frac{\alpha^{2}L^{2}\sigma_{G}^{2}}{D^{\text{in}}}=\mathcal{O}(\frac{1}{\epsilon}) with (∑i=1nUki2)​α2​L2​σG2Din≤ϵsuperscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛superscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝑈𝑘𝑖2superscript𝛼2superscript𝐿2superscriptsubscript𝜎𝐺2superscript𝐷initalic-ϵ(\sum_{i=1}^{n}{U_{k}^{i}}^{2})\frac{\alpha^{2}L^{2}\sigma_{G}^{2}}{D^{\text{in}}}\leq\epsilon is to indicate that, as long as (C4.1) is satisfied, an ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon-FOSP would be guaranteed. Note that (C4.1) is also a contraction of (C1.1). That is, as long as there exists an optimal solution to (P4), this solution is also feasible and is close to the optimal solution to (P1). We can regard the optimal solution to (P4) as an optimal approximation to (P1). (C4.2) and (C4.3) are the energy constraint and transmit power constraint on each UE, respectively.

Based on the above decomposition, we can solve the original problem (P1) by solving problem (P2), in which problems (P3) and (P4) are nested and addressed with the coordinate descent method. This decoupling only provides the approximate optimal results. However, the evaluation results show that, with the approximate optimal results obtained from (P2), (P3) and (P4), the proposed MAML-based FL algorithm always outperforms Per-FedAvg in learning time and convergence performances. Next, we deal with problems (P2), (P3), and (P4), respectively.

IV-B Problem Solution

IV-B1 Communication Round Optimization

Once the power transmit power 𝐩𝐩\mathbf{p} and the sampled data size 𝐝𝐝\mathbf{d} are obtained from the slave problem, the master problem (P2) is monotonously increasing with respect to K𝐾K. Therefore, to minimize the total training time, the optimal value of K𝐾K should be obtained as its lower bound:

K∗=4​(F​(w0)−F​(wϵ))β​ϵ,superscript𝐾4𝐹subscript𝑤0𝐹subscript𝑤italic-ϵ𝛽italic-ϵK^{*}=\frac{4(F(w_{0})-F(w_{\epsilon}))}{\beta\epsilon}, (30)

Note that, we do not use the formulation of K∗superscript𝐾K^{*} to predict the actual optimal global communication rounds. It is not practical to determine this value in advance because in practice, the optimal value of the communication rounds can be easily observed once the training loss starts to converge. There are so many factors that can affect the actual value of K∗superscript𝐾K^{*}, even the version of Pytorch/Tensorflow in the experiments! Therefore, the theoretical formulation of K∗superscript𝐾K^{*} in (31), with the initial global model w0subscript𝑤0w_{0}, the global optimal loss F​(wϵ)𝐹subscript𝑤italic-ϵF(w_{\epsilon}), the global learning rate β𝛽\beta, and the model accuracy ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon to be decided, is only used as a guidance indicating the order of magnitude of the practical optimal communication rounds.

IV-B2 Data Sample Size Optimization

It is easy to observe from problem (P3) that for each UE i𝑖i, its optimal dkisuperscriptsubscript𝑑𝑘𝑖d_{k}^{i} lies at the lower bound 1ϵ1italic-ϵ\frac{1}{\epsilon}. However, whether this lower bound can be reached depends on the relationship between the values of dkisuperscriptsubscript𝑑𝑘𝑖d_{k}^{i}’s lower bound 1ϵ1italic-ϵ\frac{1}{\epsilon} and upper bounds defined by (C3.2) and (C3.3). Specifically, the upper bound defined by (C3.2) is Dip:=2​Emaxς​ci​ϑi2−2​pki​Zς​ci​ϑi2​B​log2⁡(1+ξki)assignsuperscriptsubscript𝐷𝑖p2subscript𝐸𝜍subscript𝑐𝑖superscriptsubscriptitalic-ϑ𝑖22superscriptsubscript𝑝𝑘𝑖𝑍𝜍subscript𝑐𝑖superscriptsubscriptitalic-ϑ𝑖2𝐵subscript21superscriptsubscript𝜉𝑘𝑖D_{i}^{\text{p}}:=\frac{2E_{\max}}{\varsigma c_{i}\vartheta_{i}^{2}}-\frac{2p_{k}^{i}Z}{\varsigma c_{i}\vartheta_{i}^{2}B\log_{2}(1+\xi_{k}^{i})}, while the upper bound defined by (C3.3) is Disubscript𝐷𝑖D_{i}. Consequently, for each UE i𝑖i, we need to consider two cases: Di≥1ϵsubscript𝐷𝑖1italic-ϵD_{i}\geq\frac{1}{\epsilon} and Di<1ϵsubscript𝐷𝑖1italic-ϵD_{i}<\frac{1}{\epsilon}, in which we further discuss other two cases: Dip>1ϵsuperscriptsubscript𝐷𝑖p1italic-ϵD_{i}^{\text{p}}>\frac{1}{\epsilon} and Dip≤1ϵsuperscriptsubscript𝐷𝑖p1italic-ϵD_{i}^{\text{p}}\leq\frac{1}{\epsilon}. That is, we discuss the optimal solution of dkisuperscriptsubscript𝑑𝑘𝑖d_{k}^{i} for problem (P3) as follows.

Case 1: In this case, UE i𝑖i generates sufficient data points which are larger than or equal to its lower bound for a model accuracy ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon. That is, for each UE i𝑖i, we have

0<1ϵ≤Di.01italic-ϵsubscript𝐷𝑖0<\frac{1}{\epsilon}\leq D_{i}. (31)

Under this case, we need to further discuss the relationship between Dipsubscriptsuperscript𝐷p𝑖D^{\text{p}}_{i} and 1ϵ1italic-ϵ\frac{1}{\epsilon}:

  • •

    When Dip>1ϵsuperscriptsubscript𝐷𝑖p1italic-ϵD_{i}^{\text{p}}>\frac{1}{\epsilon}, the lower bound 1ϵ1italic-ϵ\frac{1}{\epsilon} of dkisuperscriptsubscript𝑑𝑘𝑖d_{k}^{i} can be obtained with enough data points to achieve the model accuracy ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon. Therefore, the optimal sampled data size dki=1ϵsuperscriptsubscript𝑑𝑘𝑖1italic-ϵd_{k}^{i}=\frac{1}{\epsilon}.

  • •

    When Dip≤1ϵsuperscriptsubscript𝐷𝑖p1italic-ϵD_{i}^{\text{p}}\leq\frac{1}{\epsilon}, the lower bound 1ϵ1italic-ϵ\frac{1}{\epsilon} of dkisuperscriptsubscript𝑑𝑘𝑖d_{k}^{i} cannot be achieved. According to (1) in Theorem 1, the larger disubscript𝑑𝑖d_{i} is, the higher model accuracy can be achieved. Therefore, the optimal value of dkisuperscriptsubscript𝑑𝑘𝑖d_{k}^{i} should be equal to Dipsuperscriptsubscript𝐷𝑖pD_{i}^{\text{p}}.

Case 2: In this case, UE i𝑖i creates deficient data points which are smaller than its lower bound for a model accuracy ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon. That is, for each UE i𝑖i, we have

0≤Di<1ϵ.0subscript𝐷𝑖1italic-ϵ0\leq D_{i}<\frac{1}{\epsilon}. (32)

Under this case, we also need to further discuss the relationship between Dipsubscriptsuperscript𝐷p𝑖D^{\text{p}}_{i} and 1ϵ1italic-ϵ\frac{1}{\epsilon}:

  • •

    When Dip>1ϵsubscriptsuperscript𝐷p𝑖1italic-ϵD^{\text{p}}_{i}>\frac{1}{\epsilon}, the optimal value of dkisuperscriptsubscript𝑑𝑘𝑖d_{k}^{i} is Disubscript𝐷𝑖D_{i};

  • •

    When Dip≤1ϵsubscriptsuperscript𝐷p𝑖1italic-ϵD^{\text{p}}_{i}\leq\frac{1}{\epsilon}, the optimal value of dkisuperscriptsubscript𝑑𝑘𝑖d_{k}^{i} is min⁡{Di,Dip}subscript𝐷𝑖superscriptsubscript𝐷𝑖p\min\{D_{i},D_{i}^{\text{p}}\};

The above process of computing dkisuperscriptsubscript𝑑𝑘𝑖d_{k}^{i} for problem (P3) can be summarized as SampledDataSize algorithm, which is omitted due to the space limitation.

IV-B3 Transmit Power Optimization

At last, we turn to solving problem (P4), where transmit power pkisuperscriptsubscript𝑝𝑘𝑖p_{k}^{i} for UE i𝑖i in round k𝑘k is optimized with fixed dkisuperscriptsubscript𝑑𝑘𝑖d_{k}^{i}. To this end, we first convert the problem into a more concise form. Given that Ukisuperscriptsubscript𝑈𝑘𝑖U_{k}^{i} denotes the normalized update successful probability, we have Uki≤1superscriptsubscript𝑈𝑘𝑖1U_{k}^{i}\leq 1. Then the inequality ∑inUki2≤1superscriptsubscript𝑖𝑛superscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝑈𝑘𝑖21\sum_{i}^{n}{U_{k}^{i}}^{2}\leq 1 is always true. Consequently, we can further transform (C4.1) to α2​L2​σG2Diin≤ϵsuperscript𝛼2superscript𝐿2superscriptsubscript𝜎𝐺2superscriptsubscript𝐷𝑖initalic-ϵ\frac{\alpha^{2}L^{2}\sigma_{G}^{2}}{D_{i}^{\text{in}}}\leq\epsilon. Combine the transformed constraint with (C3.1), (C3.2) and (C3.3), we find that as long as α2​L2​σG2≤min⁡{1,Di​ϵ,Dp​ϵ}superscript𝛼2superscript𝐿2superscriptsubscript𝜎𝐺21subscript𝐷𝑖italic-ϵsubscript𝐷𝑝italic-ϵ\alpha^{2}L^{2}\sigma_{G}^{2}\leq\min\{1,D_{i}\epsilon,D_{p}\epsilon\}, (C4.1) can always be satisfied. Therefore, problem (P4) can be further transformed to a new optimization problem without constraint (C4.1).

With the above concise formulation of (P4), we analyze the monotonicity of tk,icomsuperscriptsubscript𝑡𝑘𝑖comt_{k,i}^{\text{com}} in the objective function of problem (P4). Specifically, the derivative of tk,icomsuperscriptsubscript𝑡𝑘𝑖comt_{k,i}^{\text{com}} can be computed as follows:

dd​pki​tk,icom=ddsuperscriptsubscript𝑝𝑘𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑡𝑘𝑖comabsent\displaystyle\frac{\text{d}}{\text{d}p_{k}^{i}}t_{k,i}^{\text{com}}= dd​pki​ZB​log2⁡(1+ξki)ddsuperscriptsubscript𝑝𝑘𝑖𝑍𝐵subscript21superscriptsubscript𝜉𝑘𝑖\displaystyle\frac{\text{d}}{\text{d}p_{k}^{i}}\frac{Z}{B\log_{2}(1+\xi_{k}^{i})}
=\displaystyle= −Z​hi​‖ci‖−κB​N0​(1+ξki)​[log2⁡(1+ξki)]2<0,𝑍subscriptℎ𝑖superscriptnormsubscript𝑐𝑖𝜅𝐵subscript𝑁01superscriptsubscript𝜉𝑘𝑖superscriptdelimited-[]subscript21superscriptsubscript𝜉𝑘𝑖20\displaystyle-\frac{Zh_{i}\|c_{i}\|^{-\kappa}}{BN_{0}(1+\xi_{k}^{i})[\log_{2}(1+\xi_{k}^{i})]^{2}}<0, (33)

which means tk,icomsuperscriptsubscript𝑡𝑘𝑖comt_{k,i}^{\text{com}} monotonically decreases with pkisuperscriptsubscript𝑝𝑘𝑖p_{k}^{i}.

Further, as for the constraint (C4.2), the derivative of its left-hand-side term can be proved to be always larger than 0, which is shown as follows,

dd​pki​pki​ZB​log2⁡(1+ξki)ddsuperscriptsubscript𝑝𝑘𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑝𝑘𝑖𝑍𝐵subscript21superscriptsubscript𝜉𝑘𝑖\displaystyle\frac{\text{d}}{\text{d}p_{k}^{i}}p_{k}^{i}\frac{Z}{B\log_{2}(1+\xi_{k}^{i})}

where the inequality is derived from the fact that log2⁡(1+x)>x1+xsubscript21𝑥𝑥1𝑥\log_{2}(1+x)>\frac{x}{1+x}, for x>0𝑥0x>0. Therefore, the left-hand-side term of (C4.2) monotonically increases with pkisuperscriptsubscript𝑝𝑘𝑖p_{k}^{i}. It means (C4.2) defines another upper bound of pkisuperscriptsubscript𝑝𝑘𝑖p_{k}^{i} just as Pmaxsubscript𝑃P_{\max} in (C4.3).

From the above analysis, the optimal solutions to (P4) lies at the upper bound of pkisuperscriptsubscript𝑝𝑘𝑖p_{k}^{i}, which is defined by (C4.2) or (C4.3). This process of computing pkisuperscriptsubscript𝑝𝑘𝑖p_{k}^{i} can be summarized as PowerComputation algorithm, which is omitted due to space concern.

IV-C AutoFL Implementation

After devising the algorithms to determining the number of communication round K𝐾K, the sampled data size 𝐝𝐝\mathbf{d}, and the transmit power 𝐩𝐩\mathbf{p}, we are able to combine these sub-algorithms together to design the AutoFL algorithm, which is shown in Algorithm 2. Note that, to reduce the computational complexity, we only adopt the coordinate descent method to solve problem (P3) and (P4) once in one round. More specifically, given the current transmit power pk−1isuperscriptsubscript𝑝𝑘1𝑖p_{k-1}^{i}, problem (P4) with respect to dkisuperscriptsubscript𝑑𝑘𝑖d_{k}^{i} is solved for UE i∈𝒜k𝑖subscript𝒜𝑘i\in\mathcal{A}_{k} in round k𝑘k using SampledDataSize algorithm, as line 6 in AutoFL. Then, based on the obtained dkisuperscriptsubscript𝑑𝑘𝑖d_{k}^{i}, problem (P4) with respect to pkisuperscriptsubscript𝑝𝑘𝑖p_{k}^{i} is addressed for UE i∈𝒜k𝑖subscript𝒜𝑘i\in\mathcal{A}_{k} in round k𝑘k with PowerComputation algorithm, as line 7 in AutoFL. The result of pkisuperscriptsubscript𝑝𝑘𝑖p_{k}^{i} is further used in the next round k+1𝑘1k+1 to compute dk+1isuperscriptsubscript𝑑𝑘1𝑖d_{k+1}^{i} for UE i∈𝒜k𝑖subscript𝒜𝑘i\in\mathcal{A}_{k}, which is used to compute pk+1isuperscriptsubscript𝑝𝑘1𝑖p_{k+1}^{i} again. This process repeats until model accuracy ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon is achieved. As in line 15 in AutoFL, once the model accuracy is reached, the algorithm is terminated and the required number of rounds K∗superscript𝐾K^{*} is output.

V Performance Evaluation

In this section, we evaluate the performances of AutoFL to (1) verify its effectiveness in saving the learning time, (2) examine its training loss and accuracy to demonstrate its effectiveness in fast adaptation and convergence, (3) present its advantages in different network and dataset settings.

V-A Simulation Settings

V-A1 Network settings

Unless otherwise sepecified, we consider a mobile edge network that consists of n=20𝑛20n=20 UEs located in a cell of radius R=200𝑅200R=200 m and a BS located at its center. Assume that all UEs are uniformly distributed in the cell. The Rayleigh distribution parameter of hkisuperscriptsubscriptℎ𝑘𝑖h_{k}^{i} is 404040. The other parameters used in simulations are listed in Table I.

V-A2 Datasets

We evaluate the training performance using two datasets, the MNIST dataset [26] for handwritten digits classification and CIFAR-10 [27]. The network model we used for MNIST is a 2-layer NN with hidden layer of size 100, while the network model we used for CIFAR-10 is LeNet-5 [28], where there are two convolutional layers and three fully connected layers. The datasets are partitioned randomly with 75%percent7575\% and 25%percent2525\% for training and testing respectively. Meanwhile, in the simulation we use both i.i.d datasets and non-i.i.d datasets. In order to generate i.i.d datasets, the original training dataset is randomly partitioned into 20 portions and each UE is assigned a portion. As for the non-i.i.d datasets, the original training set is first partitioned into 10 portions according to the labels. Each UE has only l𝑙l of the 10 labels and is allocated a different local data size in the range of [2,3834]23834[2,3834], where l=[1,…,10]𝑙1…10l=[1,\dots,10]. The value of l𝑙l reflects the non-i.i.d level of local datasets. The smaller l𝑙l is, the higher non-i.i.d level. Unless otherwise defined, we use l=5𝑙5l=5 in the evaluation. All experiments are conducted by PyTorch [29] version 1.7.1.

V-A3 Baselines

We compare the performance of AutoFL with Per-FedAvg [14] and FedAvg [7]. FedAvg is the first algorithm that is proposed for FL and is the most general FL algorithm. Per-FedAvg, on the other hand, is the most general MAML-based FL algorithm. In Per-FedAvg, we first fix the sampled data size of all UEs to be 555. As for the transmit power settings in Per-FedAvg, all UEs use the maximal power Pmaxsubscript𝑃P_{\max}, given that there are only 5 data samples to train on each UE and more power can be saved to transmit the local updates to the BS. As for FedAvg, we consider two sets of sampled data sizes: for the first one, we set the sampled data sizes of the UEs to be 555 and the transmit power in all rounds to be Pmaxsubscript𝑃P_{\max}, which is the same with the settings with Per-FedAvg. We name the FedAvg algorithm with the first setting as FedAvg-1; For the second one, we set the sampled data sizes and transmit power of the UEs to be the same with AutoFL. We name the FedAvg with the second setting as FedAvg-2. Later, we may change the sampled data sizes in Per-FedAvg and FedAvg-1 to check the influence of the number of sampled data on the performance gap between Per-FedAvg and AutoFL.

V-B Learning Time Comparisons

We first compare the learning time of AutoFL with that of Per-FedAvg, FedAvg-1, and FedAvg-2 with respect to the test accuracy. The results are shown in Fig. 2. We analyse the results from three aspects. (i) First, it is clear that at the same accuracy, AutoFL consumes the smallest learning time. For example, when the algorithms start to converge, Per-FedAvg takes at least twice as much time as AutoFL. This is a reasonable result as AutoFL is designed to minimize the overall learning time. Meanwhile, as the test accuracy increases, the average learning time of all algorithms grows rapidly. The experimental results verify our theoretical analysis and confirms the effectiveness of AutoFL in saving the overall learning time. (ii) Second, we observe that the two MAML-based FL algorithms outperform the two conventional FL algorithms. This advantage is even more pronounced when using the non-i.i.d CIFAR-10 dataset rather than the MNIST datasets. This result testifies the advantage of MAML in accelerating the training speed of FL. Meanwhile, the two algorithms with designed sampled data size and transmit power, AutoFL and FedAvg-2 outperform Per-FedAvg and FedAvg-1. This indicates that the joint optimization of the sampled data size and transmit power is a promising way to improve the FL performance over mobile edge networks. (iii) Third, the results derived from i.i.d datasets are more stable than that from non-i.i.d datasets, meanwhile the average learning time under i.i.d datasets is smaller than that under non-i.i.d datasets. This is because, in the i.i.d case, the local model of each individual UE has a higher representative for the learned global model, which is beneficial to improve the learning performance.

Thereafter, we change the sampled data size of Per-FedAvg to see how the gap between Per-FedAvg and AutoFL would change with different number of data samples for Per-FedAvg. Note that when the number of samples increases, the transmit power of UEs in Per-FedAvg is not always Pmaxsubscript𝑃P_{\max}. Therefore, here we use the PowerComputation algorithm to compute the transmit power with the predifined data sample sizes. Fig. 3 shows the results. From Fig. 3 we observe that, no matter how does the number of data samples change in Per-FedAvg, its overall learning time is smaller than AutoFL. As the sampled data size increase from 555 to 404040, for the same test accuracy, the average learning time of Per-FedAvg is getting smaller and smaller. This phenomenon is more obvious using the CIFAR-10 dataset. However, when the number of sampled data points is 606060, the learning time performance of Per-FedAvg suddenly deteriorate. We attribute this phenomenon to the reason that the larger sampled data size requires the larger transmit power. And once the transmit power of a certain UE reaches its upper bound, it can not be improved. Due to insufficient transmit power, the uploads transmitted from this UE fail to arrive the server for global model update. Therefore, although the number of samples on each UE has increased, the learning time may have become longer and longer. This result gives us great confidence, that although the original problem (P1) is NP-hard, and AutoFL is designed to approximate the optimal solutions to (P1), the approximate results are also effective in consuming as little time as possible.

V-C Convergence Performance Comparisons

Next, we compare convergence performance of AutoFL, Per-FedAvg, FedAvg-1, and FedAvg-2, in terms of training loss and test accuracy. Specifically, the smaller the training loss is, the better the convergence performance is. On the contrary, as for the test accuracy, the larger, the better. Fig. 4 shows the convergence performance using the i.i.d MNIST, non-i.i.d MNIST and non-i.i.d CIFAR-10 datasets, respectively.

From Fig. 4, it is observed that AutoFL outperforms the other three algorithms on the two concerned metrics. This phenomenon is more obvious using the non-i.i.d CIFAR-10 dataset. Besides, AutoFL has the fastest convergence rate, which is consistent with the learning time performance, that AutoFL performs the best. This result indicates that the K∗superscript𝐾K^{*} in AutoFL is smaller than that in Per-FedAvg and FedAvg. For example, for the non-i.i.d MNIST datasets shown in Fig. 4, after about 505050 rounds, AutoFL start to converge, while Per-FedAvg starts to converge after about 707070 rounds, the two FedAvg algorithms start to converge after about 100100100 rounds.

V-D Effect of Network and Dataset Settings

To understand how different network and dataset settings, such as the radius of the cell and the data heterogeneity, affect the convergence of AutoFL, we conduct a set of experiments on the MNIST dataset.

  • •

    Effect of the radius of the cell R𝑅R: Figs. 5a and 5b show the average K∗superscript𝐾K^{*} and the highest achievable test accuracy with different radius of the cell R𝑅R. K∗superscript𝐾K^{*} is measured in number of rounds the algorithm starts to converge with test accuracy std ±1%plus-or-minuspercent1\pm 1\%. From Figs. 5a and 5b, we observe that K∗superscript𝐾K^{*} increases faster and faster with R𝑅R, while the test accuracy decreases faster and faster with R𝑅R. The hidden reason is that, with R𝑅R increasing, the number of UEs whose local updates can be successfully decoded at the BS decreases. This reduction of UEs’ participation in global model update will definitely cause increased K∗superscript𝐾K^{*} and decreased test accuracy. Besides, comparing AutoFL with Per-FedAvg, FedAvg-2 with FedAvg-1, we find that the optimization of transmit power and sampled data size on inividual UEs is beneficial to FL convergence, especially when the wireless environment becomes worse with increasing R𝑅R.

  • •

    Effect of the metric of data heterogeneity l𝑙l: The non-i.i.d level l𝑙l is used to measure the data heterogeneity. Specifically, the smaller l𝑙l is, the larger data heterogeneity is. Figs. 5c and 5d show the average K∗superscript𝐾K^{*} and the highest achievable model accuracy with respect to the non-i.i.d level l𝑙l. We can observe from the figures that as the non-i.i.d level decreases, K∗superscript𝐾K^{*} is decreasing while the test accuracy is increasing. This result is reasonable as the higher degree of data heterogeneity across UEs has more negative impact on the learning process. As expected, Figs. 5c and 5d also demonstrate that AutoFL can achieve more gains for the more heterogeneous datasets across UEs.

VI Conclusions

In this paper, we have quantified the benefit MAML brings to FL over mobile edge networks. The quantification is achieved from two aspects: the determination of FL hyperparameters (i.e., sampled data sizes and the number of communication rounds) and the resource allocation (i.e., transmit power) on individual UEs. In this regard, we have formulated an overall learning time minimization problem, constrained by the model accuracy and energy consumption at individual UEs. We have solved this optimization problem by firstly analysing the convergence rate of MAML-based FL, which is used to bound the three variables as functions of the model accuracy ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon. With these upper bounds, the optimization problem can be decoupled into three sub-problems, each of which considers one of the variables and uses the corresponding upper bound as its constraint. The first sub-problem guides the optimization of the number of communication rounds. The second and the third sub-problem are computed using the coordinate descent method, to achieve the sampled data size and the transmit power for each UE in each round respectively. Based on the solutions, we have proposed the AutoFL, a MAML-based FL algorithm that not only quantifies the benefit MAML brings to FL but also maximize such benefit to conduct fast adaptation and convergence over mobile edge networks. Extensive experimental results have verified that AutoFL outperforms Per-FedAvg and FedAvg, with the fast adaptation and convergence.

In order to prove Theorem 1, we first introduce an intermediate inference derived from the Lipschitzan gradient assumption. That is, if f​(w)𝑓𝑤f(w) is L-Lipschitz continuous, then ‖∇f​(w)−∇f​(u)‖≤L​‖w−u‖norm∇𝑓𝑤∇𝑓𝑢𝐿norm𝑤𝑢\|\nabla f(w)-\nabla f(u)\|\leq L\|w-u\| is equivalent to
